awd_titl_txt: Collaborative Research:  Summer Training Program to Broaden Participation in Graduate Education in Economics
awd_abstract_narration:
This award funds efforts by Michigan State University and Western Michigan University in hosting the American Economic Association Summer Training Program. The goal of the AEASTP is to help talented undergraduate students advance their technical skills and conduct research in economics in preparation for studies at the doctoral level. The program is open to all qualified students regardless of race, ethnicity, or gender. Organizers make special efforts to recruit students from groups under-represented in the economics profession. The program combines research experience with intensive coursework and career mentoring in a residential experience.  Instructors in the program include both leading economists and a cohort of Summer Fellows, graduate students in economics who serve as mentors for the students. Fellows get training in inclusive teaching methods and benefit from access to the faculty instructors, who work with both students and fellows as research mentors. The award will also fund a program evaluation effort that includes both ongoing efforts and long term outcomes.

The road to successful Ph.D. study in economics can be a rocky one, especially for students coming from minority-serving institutions and institutions that do not have a strong research focus. Obstacles include undergraduate economics curricula that are often oriented towards the most popular student career goal - business - than Ph.D. study, a lack of familiarity with the application process, and financial limitations. One consequence is that several important demographic groups are under-represented on economics faculties in the U.S.. Over the course of this award, hundreds of students will be able to successfully advance to become mature researchers in economics and related social sciences. Their experiences will be instrumental in their later careers in allowing them to use a strong professional network to help them foster a more inclusive environment in their own teaching and research efforts. By broadening participation in the economics profession, the program will have a positive and lasting impact on shaping professional research agendas in economics and related fields to the benefit of the United States.

por.por_cntn:
The economics profession faces challenges in terms of participation of under-represented groups and as a profession lags behind many STEM fields in current levels of participation and also in terms of trends concerning increasing the level of participation. There is considerable danger that without adequate broad participation the research agendas of the profession may be substantially misaligned with the needs the profession strives to address. This program is a significant contribution to stave off that considerable danger.

The major goals of the project were to increase the number and the success of persons from under-represented backgrounds in graduate programs in economics and related fields with the aim to broaden the scope and increase the quality of scientific inquiry in economics and related social sciences.

A two-month long mainly residential program was held in the summers of the years 2017-21 (the latter years were online due to COVID restrictions). The program included four-courses, 12 credit, taught at two levels: Foundations (undergraduate) and Advanced (beginning graduate). The program included excursions to institutions of higher education (Western Michigan and Univ. of Chicago) and to the research department of the Federal Reserve Bank of Chicago; and also had a brownbag seminar series with scholars from across the US presenting their work and giving mentoring advice to students.  

A main purpose of the Foundations level is to educate students about the necessary educational preparation for applying to graduate programs in economics and related fields and providing a solid foundation for their success in further pursuing such educational preparation. The Advanced level educates students about the necessary educational preparation for pursuing research careers in economics and related fields and providing a solid foundation for their success in pursuing such careers in PhD programs in economics and related fields. For all students the objective was to (1) Educate and foster an appreciation of the scope and breadth of economics and related research to the benefit of human understanding and informed policy-making. (2) Familiarize them with the process and subsequent prospects of graduate level training in economics and related fields.

A large component of the focus of the program is on the quantitative analysis and theoretical modeling of human (inter)actions. While these skills are at the core of modern economic research, they are applicable much more broadly throughout the social and behavioral sciences. Some of the research conducted by our students and some of the research careers pursued by program participants will overlap or entirely focus on social and behavioral sciences beyond economics.

In total over 200 students participated and the program was supported by about 100 fellows, also drawn from largely under-presented backgrounds in the economics profession. Students worked exceptionally hard in a very collaborative environment and made significant improvement in (a) their academic preparedness for their future education and career paths and (b) in their understanding of the importance of advanced research in economics and related fields. Fellows acquired additional research and mentoring skills. Through individualized mentoring, students increased their personal understanding of what their career trajectory might look like and what requirements they would need to fulfil to become successful in pursuing an advanced career in economics or related fields through graduate studies.

The program was supplemented by extensive network building, including social media presence. As a result many of the alumns are still actively engaged with one another as they are effectively pursue their careers. The Inter-university Consortium for Political and Social Research is the curator of the data associated with the program.
